facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 126 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 126 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 19, 1959, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 144 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 19, 1959, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 144 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by KAPUR, J. on March 6, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. March 6. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-

facts.text: Appellant was sitting in a third class compartment of the Amritsar Kalka train standing on Platform No. 5 of the Amritsar Railway Station on February 11, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant on February 11, 1958, when he was sitting in a third class companypartment of the Amritsa Kalka train standing on Platform No. 5 of the Amrsar Railway Station,

facts.text: Appellant was searched by a Customs Official on February 11, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: was searched by a Customs Official and some bars of gold were found tied round his waist.

facts.text: Some bars of gold were found tied round appellant's waist.

anchor.surface_text: and some bars of gold were found tied round his waist. These gold bars were seized and a recovery memo wits prepared,

facts.text: Gold bars were seized and a recovery memo was prepared.

anchor.surface_text: These gold bars were seized and a recovery memo wits prepared, Out of these gold  1  1962 3. S.C.R. 786. bars

facts.text: Out of the gold bars, four were of base metal and the rest were of pure gold.

anchor.surface_text: Out of these gold  1  1962 3. S.C.R. 786. bars four were of base metal and the rest were of pure gold some bearing

facts.text: Some gold bars bore the stamp of Johmon Mathey Co. Ltd., 999-10 tolas.

anchor.surface_text: and 2-1/4 bars bore marks of N.M. Rothschild Sons 10 tolas  990-0 . No permit from the the Reserve Bank to import this gold

facts.text: No permit from the Reserve Bank to import the gold was produced by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: No permit from the the Reserve Bank to import this gold was produced by the appellant. Under the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1917,

facts.text: Appellant prosecuted under s.23A of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act and s.167(81) of the Sea Customs Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was prosecuted under s.23A of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act and 167 81  of the Sea Customs Act and his defence

facts.text: Appellant's defence was that he was not in possession of the gold bars which were taken from an attache case left by a stranger under the seat.

anchor.surface_text: and his defence was that he was number in possession of the gold bars which were taken from an attache case left by a stranger under the seat where he  the appellant  was sitting.

facts.text: Additional District Magistrate held the offence proved, convicted appellant and sentenced to one year rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional District Magistrate held the offence to be proved and companyvicted the appellant of the offence and sentenced him to one years rigorous imprison- ment.

facts.text: Appeal to Sessions Judge resulted in reduction of sentence to 8 months rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal to the Sessions Judge resulted in the reduction of the sentence to 8 months rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: On revision to High Court, sentence reduced to six months rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: On revision to the High Court the sentence was reduced to six months rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Appellant came in appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has companye in appeal by special leave.

facts.text: Trial court accepted testimony of Customs Officials, held defence false, gold worth Rs. 14,000/- found in possession of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt accepted the testimony of the Customs Officials and held that the defence of the appellant was false and that gold worth Rs. 14,000/- was found in his possession.

facts.text: Sessions Judge accepted testimony of Customs Officials, held defence false, gold found in possession of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge in appeal also accepted the testimony of the Customs Officials and held the defence to be false and came to the companyclusion that the gold was found in possession

facts.text: High Court rejected the same plea.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court the same plea was taken and was rejected.

facts.text: Two Customs officers appeared as witnesses: Inspector Satnam Singh and Deputy Superintendent A.N. Kapur.

issues.text: Whether s.178A of the Sea Customs Act, 1878 is constitutional

anchor.surface_text: raises the constitutionality of s.178A of the Sea Customs Act., 1878  Act 8 of 1878 , which has been held by this Court to be constitutional in the Collector of Castoms, Madras v. Nathella Sampathu Chetty 1 .

issues.text: Whether before the presumption under s.178A can be made applicable, it must be proved by the prosecution that the goods were of foreign origin i.e. had been imported from abroad

anchor.surface_text: For the first time in this Court it is contended that before the presumption under s.178A can be made applicable, it must be proved by the prosecution that the goods were of foreign origin, i.e. had beep imported from abroad and only then does the presumption under s. 178A arise

arguments.claim: s.178A of the Sea Customs Act, 1878 is unconstitutional

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment and order of the High Court of the Punjab and raises the constitutionality of s.178A of the Sea Customs Act., 1878  Act 8 of 1878 , which has been held by this Court to be constitutional in the Collector of Castoms, Madras v. Nathella Sampathu Chetty 1 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n held by this Court to be companystitutional in t

arguments.court_reasoning: Previously held constitutional by Supreme Court in Collector of Customs, Madras v. Nathella Sampathu Chetty

arguments.claim: Before presumption under s.178A applies, prosecution must prove goods were of foreign origin i.e. imported from abroad

anchor.surface_text: For the first time in this Court it is contended that before the presumption under s.178A can be made applicable, it must be proved by the prosecution that the goods were of foreign origin, i.e. had beep imported from abroad and only then does the presumption under s. 178A arise which relates only to the question of Customs duty having been paid.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not the effect of s.178A; burden shifts upon seizure in reasonable belief smuggled, which includes not foreign origin without duty; onus not on prosecution to prove origin

arguments.claim: There must be evidence in support of the reasonableness of the Customs Officer's belief that goods were smuggled goods for s.178A to apply

anchor.surface_text: At the time, of arguments before us a further point was raised that in order that s.178A of the Sea Customs Act may become applicable, the prosecution must further prove that the goods which were sought to be affected by the order of the Customs Officer were goods of foreign origin and there must be evidence in support of the reasonableness of the belief of the Customs Officer that the goods were smuggled goods.

arguments.claim: Under s.178A, where goods seized in reasonable belief smuggled, burden on person from possession to prove not smuggled (not foreign origin without duty paid)

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that this question has never been raised, that is number the effect of s.178A of the Sea Customs Act which provides- 178A.  1  Where any goods to which this section applies are seized under this Act in the reasonable belief that they are smuggled goods, the burden of proving that they are number smuggled goods shall be on the person from whose possession the goods were seized... The onus is number on the prosecution to show that the goods are number, of Indian origin.

holdings.text: Section 178A of the Sea Customs Act, 1878 is constitutional.

anchor.surface_text: which has been held by this Court to be constitutional in the Collector of Customs, Madras v. Nathella Sampathu Chetty 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on binding precedent from this Court in Collector of Customs, Madras v. Nathella Sampathu Chetty.

holdings.text: The presumption under s.178A applies upon seizure of goods in reasonable belief they are smuggled; prosecution need not prove foreign origin; burden shifts to possessor to prove goods not smuggled i.e. not foreign origin without duty paid.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that this question has never been raised, that is not the effect of s.178A of the Sea Customs Act which provides- 178A. 1 Where any goods to which this section applies are seized under this Act in the reasonable belief that they are smuggled goods,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of s.178A; defines 'smuggled goods' scope; onus shifts immediately upon qualifying seizure without prior proof of origin by prosecution.

holdings.text: No separate proof required by prosecution of reasonableness of belief for s.178A; here, Customs officers had reasonable belief goods were smuggled.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing to indicate in their cross-examination that the officers did not have a reasonable belief that the goods were smuggled goods and the question that the officers did not have reasonable belief is not suggested either from the cross-examination of these witnesses of from the findings

holdings.reasoning_summary: Question not raised below; no evidence in cross-exam disproving belief; lower courts' findings and foreign stamps support reasonable belief inherent in seizure.

holdings.text: The Customs officers had reasonable belief that the seized gold bars were smuggled goods.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing to indicate in their cross-examination that the officers did not have a reasonable belief that the goods were smuggled goods

holdings.reasoning_summary: Witness credibility intact; no challenge in cross-examination or lower court findings; circumstances including foreign markings justify belief.

holdings.text: Appellant was in possession of the gold bars triggering s.178A presumption; failed to discharge burden of proving not smuggled.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court accepted the testimony of the Customs Officials and held that the defence of the appellant was false and that gold worth Rs. 14,000/- was found in his possession. The learned Sessions Judge in appeal also accepted the testimony of the Customs Officials and held the defence to be false

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts lower courts' concurrent findings on credibility of Customs testimony over appellant's defence; possession established for s.178A application.
